008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.util.progress;
010
011import imagingbook.common.filter.generic.GenericFilter;
012import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ij.ProgressBarMonitor;
013
014/**
015 * This class represents a "progress monitor". This is a simple
016 * {@link Thread} that queries the attached target task 
017 * (implementing {@link ProgressReporter}) and calls its 
018 * {@link #handleProgress(double, long)} method at regular intervals.
019 * 
020 * {@link ProgressMonitor} implements the {@link AutoCloseable} and thus can
021 * (and should) be used in a try-with-resources context, e.g.,
022 * <pre>
023 * ProgressReporter task = ....; // the task to be monitored
024 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new MyProgressMonitor(task)) {
025 *     // run task ...
026 * }</pre>
027 * Otherwise, if not used in a auto-start/close mode, the methods {@link #start()} 
028 * and {@link #close()} should be used to "manually" start and terminate
029 * monitoring.
030 * See {@link GenericFilter} and {@link ProgressBarMonitor} for an example.
031 */
032public abstract class ProgressMonitor extends Thread implements AutoCloseable {
033        
034        public static int DefaultWaitTime = 250; // ms
035        
036        private int waitTime = DefaultWaitTime;
037        private final ProgressReporter target;
038
039        private boolean running;
040        private long startTime, endTime;
041        
042        /**
043         * Constructor, starts monitoring immediately.
044         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
045         * method is called it regular intervals.
046         * 
047         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
048         */
049        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target) {
050                this(target, true);
051        }
052        
053        /**
054         * Constructor, optionally starts monitoring immediately or waits
055         * for its {@link #start()} method to be called (which starts the 
056         * associated thread).
057         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
058         * method is called it regular intervals.
059         * 
060         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
061         * @param autoStart starts immediately if true
062         */
063        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target, boolean autoStart) {
064                if (target == null)
065                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("null target instance!");
066                this.target = target;
067                if (autoStart) {
068                        start();
069                }
070        }
071        
072        /**
073         * The time interval between progress queries can be set with this method.
074         * See also {@link #DefaultWaitTime}.
075         * 
076         * @param waitTime the time interval (in milliseconds)
077         */
078        public void setWaitTime(int waitTime) {
079                this.waitTime = waitTime;
080        }
081        
082        /**
083         * Abstract method to be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
084         * It is called by the {@link ProgressMonitor} thread in regular intervals.
085         * Current progress data are passed.
086         * It is up to the implementation what action should be performed,
087         * e.g., display the current progress graphically 
088         * (see e.g. {@link ProgressBarMonitor}).
089         * 
090         * @param progress the current progress value [0,1)
091         * @param elapsedNanoTime the time elapsed since the progress monitor was started (in nanoseconds)
092         */
093        public abstract void handleProgress(double progress, long elapsedNanoTime);
094        
095        // --------------------------------------------------------
096
097        @Override
098        public void run() {
099                handleProgress(0, 0);
100                this.startTime = System.nanoTime();
101                running = true;
102                do {
103                        try {
104                                Thread.sleep(waitTime);
105                        } catch (InterruptedException e) {break;}
106                        handleProgress(target.getProgress(), System.nanoTime() - startTime);
107                } while(running);
108                this.endTime = System.nanoTime();
109        }
110        
111        @Override
112        public void close() {
113                running = false;
114        this.interrupt();
115        }
116        
117        // --------------------------------------------------------
118        
119        /**
120         * Returns the time elapsed since monitoring started (in seconds).
121         * @return the elapsed time in seconds
122         */
123        public double getElapsedTime() { // result is in seconds
124                if (running) {
125                        return  (System.nanoTime() - startTime) / 1E9d;
126                }
127                else {
128                        return (endTime - startTime) / 1E9d;
129                }
130        }
131
132}
